question: 間
sourceAnswer:
<read>あいだ</read>|<read>あわい</read>:: space-(between)/gap/interval/distance/stretch | period-of-time-(during,-while)/duration/interval | between-(two-parties-or-things) | among-(a-group) | relations-(between)/relationship | midpoint/average/halfway/middle-ground | due-to/because-of
<read>ま</read>:: time/pause | space | room
<read>かん</read>:: interval/period-of-time | among/between/inter- | good-opportunity/chance | estrangement/discord/alienation | spy/secret-agent
sourceMnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

Don't confuse this with <ja>〜間</ja> which is similar in meaning but different in reading. The <ja>〜間</ja> means it's attached to something. This is a standalone word.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. <ja>間</ja> has two common kun'yomi readings, <ja>あいだ</ja> and <ja>ま</ja>. You haven't learned these readings yet, so here's an explanation of each reading and mnemonics to help you remember them: 

When <ja>間</ja> refers to a longer interval of time, it's generally read as <ja>あいだ</ja>. For a short burst of time, it's read as <ja>ま</ja>. When it means an interval of space, it's usually read as <ja>あいだ</ja>. 

You can remember this because time feels longer in <reading>Ida</reading>ho (<ja>あいだ</ja>). Any interval of time you spend there feels so long, because Idaho life moves so slowly. As soon as you cross the border and enter a new state, you call your <reading>ma</reading> (<ja>ま</ja>) to tell her you're finally out of that slooooow state, and the intervals of time feel shorter.
